ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about how disability intersects in the lives of Black people, ranging from social, political, and environmental realms.
I learned how to apply an intersectional approach to disability studies and ask critical questions about the context in which primary sources are produced

In this class I learned about the unspoken history that created the connection between race and disability. We discussed the debilitating effects of systemic racism on African Americans and noted the ways that contemporary disability studies and disability activists have failed to include African Americans in its sphere of consciousness.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Major strength in this course was the content every week  learned something new and it was incredible. One weakness was that sometimes the readings were long, but they were really important.
Incredible course on an under-discussed but very important topic. Greatly appreciated our discussions and the professor's ability to build community despite the challenges of the semester.
This course was spectacularly done with a very kind instructor who listened and adapted to students' needs.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Henry did an amazing job at checking in with her students and giving time at the beginning to connect and hear from her students, which made having discussions much more fun and interesting.

One of the greater successes of this course  was the flexibility of the instructor.

Kelsey implemented class note takers, relaxed readings during difficult times, and gave extensions very generously (if you asked reasonably)

I loved the ways Professor Henry helped foster community in the class through the fun check-in questions. I also really enjoyed hearing people present on different course readings because it allowed me to walk through people's thought processes while reading the texts and compare that to what I got out of the texts.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! Professor Henry is amazing I definitely recommend taking the chance to learn some amazing topics on Black life.
yes! Kelsey is the kindest human and the subject of the class is so so important.
Yes, take it because the content is eye opening and the professor is spectacular and dedicated.

I would highly recommend this class. Professor Henry is amazing and although the course materials were depressing at times, this is an extremely important topic that I think everyone should be exposed to, especially anyone interested in one day working with people of color.

Black Disability Studies was one of the best classes I had ever taken at Yale. There are very few disability studies classes offered at Yale, yet alone one that delves into the important intersections between Black studies and critical disability studies. This class has taught me to re-think a lot of previous concepts I've learned in past HSHM courses through many avenues that I had never considered before. Professor Henry is also such an amazing professor and mentor who is always delighted to share her knowledge with class while holding space for everyone's thoughts and learning processes. I would 100% recommend this class to any student at Yale!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
